title: Question 79

children: A 39-year-old man is evaluated 6 hours after he awoke with left facial droop and impaired taste. Symptoms seem slightly worse compared with this morning. He has no history of previous neurologic symptoms. He takes no medications.
Vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals weakness of the left upper and lower facial muscles, including the inability to close his left eye. Otherwise, the examination is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacologic treatment?

The peripheral facial nerve involvement seen in Bell palsy causes widespread facial paralysis, including paralysis of upper and lower facial muscles and an inability to close the eyes tightly or raise the eyebrows.
Early treatment of Bell palsy with oral glucocorticoids, usually a 10-day course of prednisone, increases the probability of recovery if initiated within the first 72 hours.
This patient has acute onset of Bell palsy and should receive prednisone (

). Mounting evidence implicates an inflammatory/infectious cause of Bell palsy that is most likely due to human herpesvirus 1. The peripheral facial nerve involvement seen in Bell palsy causes widespread facial paralysis, including paralysis of upper and lower facial muscles and an inability to close the eyes tightly or raise the eyebrows. Patients also report dry mouth, hyperacusis, impaired taste, and pain and numbness near the ear. Abrupt onset with building symptoms over 1 to 2 days is typical. Early treatment with oral glucocorticoids, usually a 10-day course of prednisone, increases the probability of recovery if initiated within the first 72 hours. Patients with impaired eye closure should be advised to use lubricating eyedrops/ointment and nighttime eye taping to prevent corneal damage. If ocular symptoms of pain, itching, or irritation occur, referral to an ophthalmologist is recommended.
Aspirin, and in some cases, dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and clopidogrel (

), may be offered if there is clinical suspicion for a stroke. This patient exhibits a peripheral pattern of facial weakness, which is not typical for stroke, and does not have any other neurologic deficits. Isolated peripheral facial palsy in this patient favors Bell palsy.
The use of antiviral agents, such as famciclovir (

), as monotherapy for Bell palsy has not been shown to be helpful. The benefit of adding antiviral treatment to prednisone is less clear, and guidelines differ in their recommendations. Although adding antiviral treatment to prednisone in patients with severe palsy may have some benefit, it is modest at best.
High-dose intravenous glucocorticoids, such as methylprednisolone (

), may be used to treat acute exacerbations of multiple sclerosis (MS) but are not indicated in the treatment of Bell palsy. This patient is less likely to have MS, because the pattern of facial weakness is more suggestive of a peripheral process (involvement of both upper and lower facial muscles) than a central process (involvement limited to lower facial muscles).

references: George E, Richie MB, Glastonbury CM. Facial nerve palsy: clinical practice and cognitive errors. Am J Med. 2020;133:1039-1044.
